Few lines of comment from Stifel.

BE11:14am

GKN reiterates that the Melrose offer “fundamentally undervalues the Company and its prospects”, which implies the Dana discussions might (theoretically) imply a higher value than the Melrose proposal. It does however appear that discussions are in the relatively early stages; indeed GKN says there can be no certainty as to the terms (if any) that might ultimately be agreed.

This is probably an unwelcome development from Melrose’s perspective given our view that a competing bid – if high enough – could derail Melrose’s proposal. Note however, that GKN has had no shortage of suitors for the separate divisions historically, and we suspect has been approached by Dana in the past.

Moreover, much of the political noise of late has been about protecting the UK industrial manufacturing base; it is hard to see how these concerns would be placated by a sale of half of GKN’s business to an overseas buyer.

GKN advises “shareholders to take no action”. We expect a response from Melrose in due course.

BE11:18am

We believe GKN's announcement illustrates the possibilities
that could open up after the demerger of Automotive and Aerospace. Now that GKN plans to demerge Aerospace and Automotive in mid-2019, the possibility of mergers, joint ventures and alliances have entered our thinking. The spin-off of businesses by GKN's wider Automotive peers have often been claimed to provide the independent businesses with strategic flexibility. We are bound to observe that the acquisition of GKN Driveline by Dana looks like a challenging transaction, even if there is a pleasing air of serendipity about the idea. We would not rule out Dana being a potential interested party in the OffHighway Powertrain business, identified by GKN as Non-Core. GKN, however, believes the possible transaction with Dana could provide greater value to shareholders, as compared with the Melrose offer. We figure that is plausible. An equity-heavy structure strikes us as not compelling, but it could be tax efficient.

BE11:18am

RBG has reported adj EBITDA of £8.9m in line with NUMe (£9.0m). Following prior period adjustments, 1H17 EBITDA was restated to £8.7m. As expected, there was only a small (£0.2m) improvement in the period as New Years Eve fell into 2H18 (given changes in year end). This had an adverse profit impact of £0.5m, meaning the underlying growth in adj EBITDA was 8.5%.

BE11:47am

Trading has slowed somewhat in H2 to date, with lfl sales -2% in the most recent seven weeks. This has mainly impacted food sales, where the company has chosen not to discount (to preserve GM) whereas "wet sales have held up well". The company expects this slowdown to be temporary, but to be prudent, and given the weather disruption in February, we move our lfl sales assumption from 1.5% to 1.0%. This results in a 2.5% reduction in our FY18E adj EBITDA to £16.0m.

BE11:47am

BE11:49am

Valuation & recommendation: RBG now trades on a FY18 P/E of 10.8x before preopening
costs or 12.8x once these are included. Our favoured valuation approach is to look at FCF yield exc. growth capex but after opening costs; applying a target yield of 7% to our forecast of £7.1m supports our target price of 200p. We see the rollout of new sites as the key value driver, rather than ST trading and remain confident that the group is executing well.
